verses.text: A wise woman builds her house, but a foolish one tears it down with her own hands.
verses.comment: The house here represents both family and one’s spiritual legacy. The wisdom praised is both practical and spiritual, pointing toward stewardship in home and faith.

verses.text: Those who walk uprightly fear the LORD, but those who are crooked in their ways despise Him.
verses.comment: Walking uprightly signifies living faithfully according to God’s commands. The verse shows that reverence for God leads to moral living, echoing the connection between faith and works.

verses.text: A fool’s speech invites punishment, but the lips of the wise protect them.
verses.comment: Words reveal the heart; wisdom protects from the consequences of sin. See James 3:2 for the New Testament’s teaching on the tongue.

verses.text: Where there are no oxen, the manger is clean, but abundant crops come by the strength of oxen.
verses.comment: This highlights how fruitful labor requires effort and investment. The principle finds echo in the call to fruitful stewardship and active service (see Matthew 25:14-30).

verses.text: A trustworthy witness does not lie, but a false witness breathes out lies.
verses.comment: Truthfulness is a foundational moral duty, anticipated in the commandments and further fulfilled in Christ, who is ‘the Truth’ (John 14:6).

verses.text: A scoffer seeks wisdom and finds none, but knowledge comes easily to one with understanding.
verses.comment: Humility opens the path to wisdom, while pride blinds. Genuine understanding starts with an attitude of faith.

verses.text: Leave the presence of a fool, for there is no wise speech to be heard there.
verses.comment: The call to separate from folly is echoed in Psalm 1; spiritual companionship affects character.

verses.text: The wisdom of the prudent is to understand their way, but the folly of fools is deceiving.
verses.comment: Prudence means self-examination and honest discernment — a virtue celebrated throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Fools mock at guilt, but among the upright there is favor.
verses.comment: Recognition of guilt opens the way for mercy and grace, echoing themes of confession and absolution (see Psalm 32:1-2).

verses.text: The heart knows its own bitterness, and no stranger can share its joy.
verses.comment: The unique experience of individual suffering and joy implies the mystery of the soul’s relationship with God.

verses.text: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, but the tent of the upright will flourish.
verses.comment: Eternal prosperity is promised to the upright; transience to the wicked. The tent suggests humble origins, yet flourishing by grace.

verses.text: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end leads to death.
verses.comment: Human perception is often limited; true wisdom requires divine guidance. This forewarns against spiritual pride and shows the need for continual guidance by God.

verses.text: Even in laughter the heart may ache, and joy may end in sorrow.
verses.comment: Temporary happiness cannot replace lasting peace. True joy is spiritual, found fully in God.

verses.text: The backslider in heart will be filled with his own ways, but a good man will be satisfied from above.
verses.comment: God’s satisfaction comes by grace, not self-effort. Spiritual nourishment is promised to those who persevere in faith.

verses.text: The simple believes every word, but the prudent considers his steps.
verses.comment: Prudence commends diligence in discerning truth. The virtue of careful reasoning is foundational for right faith.

verses.text: A wise man fears and turns away from evil, but a fool is reckless and careless.
verses.comment: To fear the Lord and depart from evil is a recurring biblical theme, pointing to spiritual wisdom and virtue.

verses.text: A quick-tempered person acts foolishly, and one who schemes is hated.
verses.comment: Uncontrolled anger leads to folly. Patience is a fruit of the Spirit (see Galatians 5:22).

verses.text: The simple inherit folly, but the wise are crowned with knowledge.
verses.comment: The crown suggests spiritual reward. Seeking God’s wisdom brings lasting honor.

verses.text: The evil bow down before the good, and the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
verses.comment: Justice will be manifest; the upright are vindicated in the end, echoing the promise of God’s final judgment.

verses.text: The poor are hated even by their neighbor, but the rich have many friends.
verses.comment: This reveals the brokenness of human relationships, and contrasts with the teaching of Christ to love the poor and marginalized.

verses.text: Those who despise their neighbor sin, but blessed are those who show kindness to the poor.
verses.comment: Compassion for the poor is repeatedly blessed, a theme emphasized by Christ (Matthew 25:40).

verses.text: Those who plot evil go astray, but steadfast love and faithfulness belong to those who plan what is good.
verses.comment: Steadfast love and faithfulness are hallmarks of the faithful, both in Old Testament and fulfilled in Christ’s life.

verses.text: In all hard work there is profit, but mere talk leads only to poverty.
verses.comment: Diligence is blessed; faith manifests in action, as echoed in James 2:17.

verses.text: The crown of the wise is their wealth, but the folly of fools brings only foolishness.
verses.comment: Spiritual riches are preeminent, suggesting that ‘crown’ refers not only to material but spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: A truthful witness saves lives, but a false witness utters lies.
verses.comment: Truth protects and gives life, a foreshadowing of Christ’s saving testimony.

verses.text: In the fear of the LORD one has strong confidence, and His children will have refuge.
verses.comment: Fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom and protection for the faithful and their children, indicating a communal aspect of faith.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, turning people away from the traps of death.
verses.comment: Fountain imagery anticipates Christ as the source of living water (see John 4:14).

verses.text: A large population is the king’s glory, but without people a ruler is ruined.
verses.comment: Leadership finds strength in serving others; this applies both to earthly rulers and spiritual leaders.

verses.text: Whoever is slow to anger has great understanding, but someone with a quick temper shows foolishness.
verses.comment: Patience is praised as wisdom; it is also a mark of spiritual maturity.

verses.text: A tranquil heart gives life to the body, but envy rots the bones.
verses.comment: Inner peace nourishes the entire person, a connection between spiritual and physical well-being.

verses.text: Those who oppress the poor insult their Maker, but those who show kindness to the needy honor Him.
verses.comment: Serving the poor is viewed as service to God Himself, a major theme later taught by Christ (see Matthew 25:40).

verses.text: The wicked are cast down by their own evil, but even in death the righteous have a refuge.
verses.comment: The righteous are promised hope beyond death, prefiguring Christian beliefs about resurrection and eternal life.

verses.text: Wisdom rests in the heart of those who have understanding, but among fools she is made known.
verses.comment: Wisdom quietly dwells with the faithful but is exposed as lacking among fools. The ‘she’ alludes to Wisdom’s personification throughout Proverbs, foreshadowing Christ as Wisdom incarnate (see 1 Corinthians 1:24).

verses.text: Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a disgrace to any people.
verses.comment: The well-being of communities is tied to righteousness, hinting at the universal call to holiness.

verses.text: A king delights in a servant who acts wisely, but his wrath falls on one who brings shame.
verses.comment: Service marked by wisdom is honored, a principle spiritualized by Jesus’ teaching about faithful servants (see Matthew 25:21).
